Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cincinnati group is expert in Flavor Physics and continues to make significant contributions to the physics of charm and heavy quarks. These contributions have come most recently through participation in the BaBar Experiment, whose active operations have ended, but whose data legacy is extensive and is being currently mined for important physics results. The Cincinnati group is now transitioning to the LHCb experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider, which is currently in an intense data-taking phase for 2012, and which will segue into an analysis and upgrade phase during the period 2013-2014.

In the physics of BaBar, Cincinnati is focusing on a mixing analysis of neutral D decays, on a precision measurement of the mass difference between charged and neutral D mesons, and absolute mass measurements of charged and neutral D mesons. At LHCb the group will work on charm mixing and CP Violation, studies that can assess indirectly high mass scales and provide powerful constraints on models for new physics beyond the standard model. Among the processes of interest are three-body decays of neutral D mesons with Kshort mesons in the final state and amplitude analyses of four-body neutral D decays. Technically, the group intends to make contributions to the LHCb High Level Trigger with emphasis on increasing the efficiency of charm decays, and notably increasing the sensitivity to triggering on Kshort mesons. For the LHCb upgrades, the group will be working on tracking simulation, and in the domain of core computing, the group will contribute to the maintenance of the Conditions Database.

The Cincinnati group has a strong record in education and outreach, and has had a very active QuarkNet Center since 2004, which offers local and regional high school teachers and students several opportunities. Among these are opportunities for teachers and students to participate directly in the research program; participation in QuarkNet International Masterclasses; and through their annual Teachers' Institute, the group has helped local high school teachers introduce particle physics and related topics in modern physics into their courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals identified in the proposal were to analyze data from the BaBar experiment at SLAC while we fully engaged as participants in the LHCb experiment at CERN.  In terms of intellectual merit, personnel supported by this award were principal analysts/authors of 5 papers published in refereed journals.  Three, using data from BaBar, reported high precision measurements of charm meson properties (a mass, a mass difference, and a natural line width). One, using data from BaBar, reported measurements of "mixing parmaters" describing the oscillations of D0 mesons into their corresponding antiparticles, and vice versa. One, using data from LHCb, compared high precision measurements of D0 mesons oscillating into their corresponding antiparticles with those of the antiparticles into D0 mesons. The rates were consistent with being the same, with an uncertainty +- 5%. A statistically significant difference from zero would indicate "Charge-Parity violation" (CPV) and provide evidence for physics beyond the Standard Model. 

Additional analyses of both BaBar and LHCb data moved towards publication during the award period.  An extension of our LHCb charm mixing and CPV analysis has been submitted for publication. This data from which the mixing rates and level of CPV are extracted are illustrated in the figure included with this report. An analysis of BaBar data that will provide a precise difference of charged and neutral D meson masses was essentially completed during the award period and is now in the last stage of collaboration review before submission for publication.

In addition to analyzing data from the LHCb experiment, we participated actively in its operation while acquiring data.  Our group had two main areas of responsibility: (i) maintaining conditions databases and (ii) developing charm triggers. The latter are the software-level selections of data to be written to permanent storage for later analysis.

We also worked on beam tests of hardware to be installed for Run 3, which should start taking data circa 2021. 

In terms of broader impact, we provided opportunities for a dozen high school students, half a dozen undergraduates, and two Ph.D. students to participate in research.  We also employed a post-doctoral fellow who has since become a tenure-track faculty member at Wuhan University in China.
